description: Octavan primes: primes of the form p = x^8 + y^8.
comments: The largest known octavan prime is currently the largest known generalized Fermat prime: The 1353265-digit 145310^262144+1 = (145310^32768)^8+1^8, found by Ricky L Hubbard. - Jens Kruse Andersen, Mar 20 2011
references: A. J. C. Cunningham, High quartan factorisations and primes, Messenger of Mathematics, 36, 11 (1907), pp. 145-174.
A. J. C. Cunningham, Binomial Factorisations, Vols. 1-9, Hodgson, London, 1923-1929; see Vol. 1, pp. 245-259.
N. J. A. Sloane and Simon Plouffe, The Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences, Academic Press, 1995 (includes this sequence).
links: T. D. Noe, Table of n, a(n) for n = 1..1000
A. J. C. Cunningham, Binomial Factorisations, Vols. 1-9, Hodgson, London, 1923-1929. [Annotated scans of a few pages from Volumes 1 and 2]
mathematica: lst={}; Do[If[PrimeQ[a^8+b^8], AppendTo[lst, a^8+b^8]], {a, 100}, {b, a, 100}]; Sort[lst] (T. D. Noe)Union[Select[Total/@(Tuples[Range[30],2]^8),PrimeQ]] (* _Harvey P. Dale_, Apr 06 2013 *)
author: _N. J. A. Sloane_.
extensions: Corrected and extended by _Jud McCranie_, Jan 04 2001
